abstract.p: Article describes indelible moment from 2006-7 theater season, technological touches introduced into Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice in Theater for a New Audience production; photo (M)

block.p: In ''The Merchant of Venice,'' when Tubal learned the whereabouts of his friend Shylock's runaway daughter, Jessica, Shylock didn't have to wait long for the news in the Theater for a New Audience production this year. He got a call from Tubal on his cellphone.

The moment, however, wasn't played for comedy, as the anachronism easily might have been. Shylock's anguish at having lost a daughter and part of his fortune to a Christian husband registered just as acutely -- perhaps more so -- for the Jewish father having no friend by his side to comfort him, only that friend's distant, mechanized voice.
Darko Tresnjak’s sleek, modern-day production of “The Merchant of Venice” was littered with technological touches.

In ''The Merchant of Venice,'' when Tubal learned the whereabouts of his friend Shylock's runaway daughter, Jessica, Shylock didn't have to wait long for the news in the Theater for a New Audience production this year. He got a call from Tubal on his cellphone.

The moment, however, wasn't played for comedy, as the anachronism easily might have been. Shylock's anguish at having lost a daughter and part of his fortune to a Christian husband registered just as acutely -- perhaps more so -- for the Jewish father having no friend by his side to comfort him, only that friend's distant, mechanized voice.

Darko Tresnjak's sleek, modern-day production in February, starring F. Murray Abraham as Shylock, was littered with such technological touches. Adjusting his position onstage to receive a better signal, Portia's preening assistant received calls from her suitors on a cordless headset. The three famous caskets containing the riddles the suitors have to answer to win Portia's hand were Mac PowerBooks. When activated, each laptop released a bells-and-whistles video letting the would-be husband know if he had chosen well or badly.

In another director's hands these flourishes might have seemed like so much eye-catching tinsel. But Mr. Tresnjak fully integrated them into his vision of a modern-day Venice as chilly, sleek and calculating as any Wall Street house: a world where all exchanges -- monetary, marital, fraternal, emotional -- are coolly commodified, and where any weakness is quickly exploited and the raid then rationalized as ''just business.''
